G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody order “may be modified if the Court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.”

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Honorable Court has jurisdiction over the subject matter and the parties pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 215, § 6.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Honorable Court has jurisdiction over the subject matter and the parties pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 215, § 6.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 31, joint legal custody determinations must reflect an ability of parents to cooperate and communicate; when that ability deteriorates, modification may be appropriate. See Rolde, supra; Mason, supra; Yannas, supra.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts law requires both a material change in circumstances and a showing that modification serves the child’s best interests. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); G.L. c. 208, § 28.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas concerns an initial divorce judgment involving custody and removal, not a post-judgment modification proceeding. The opinion interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30 and articulates the ‘real advantage’/best interests standard for removal, but it does not require or even discuss a predicate showing of a material change in circumstances as a condition to modifying an existing order. Thus it does not support the specific proposition that Massachusetts law requires both a material change and best interests for modification.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents…shall not…be removed out of this commonwealth…unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts law requires both a material change in circumstances and a showing that modification serves the child’s best interests. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); G.L. c. 208, § 28.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, and frames the standard as whether removal is in the child’s best interests; it does not state that a party must first demonstrate a material change in circumstances for modification. The only explicit reference to “substantial change in circumstances” appears in a quoted ALI Principles passage in a footnote, describing a model approach rather than announcing Massachusetts law. The holding and analysis focus purely on a best‑interests determination for removal, so citing Mason as authority that Massachusetts requires both a material change and best interests is not accurate.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that “[a] minor child of divorced parents ... shall not ... be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth ... without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.” “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.” Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985), citing Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976).

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard remains the paramount consideration.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The concurrence is focused primarily on statutory interpretation and relocation in the paternity context, not on restating the global standard for custody cases. However, it approvingly quotes Custody of Kali for the principle that maintaining an existing parenting arrangement is ordinarily in the child's best interests and that disrupting stability is generally contrary to those best interests. This reinforces that the "best interests of the child"—particularly the child's need for stability—remain the paramount consideration when fashioning custody and visitation orders, even though the opinion does not explicitly frame it as a broad doctrinal restatement.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) (“If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child”).

Anderson v. Anderson, 407 Mass. 251 (199.proposition: The Court has recognized that a substantial change in a child’s schooling or welfare can justify modification of custody. See Anderson v. Anderson, 407 Mass. 251 (1990); Custody of Sorrel, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 903 (1998).
Anderson v. Anderson, 407 Mass. 251 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion in Anderson v. Anderson concerns paternity, child support arrears, and Rule 60(b) relief from a prior divorce decree. It does not discuss custody, standards for custody modification, or how changes in a child’s schooling or welfare might justify modifying custody. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that a substantial change in schooling or welfare can justify modification of custody.

Custody of Sorrel, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 903.raw_text: Custody of Sorrel, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 903 (1998)
Custody of Sorrel, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 903.proposition: The Court has recognized that a substantial change in a child’s schooling or welfare can justify modification of custody. See Anderson v. Anderson, 407 Mass. 251 (1990); Custody of Sorrel, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 903 (1998).
Custody of Sorrel, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 903.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case involving armed robbery, carjacking, and related offenses; it does not concern child custody, schooling, or modification of custody orders. Nothing in the text addresses standards for changing custody based on a child’s schooling or welfare, so it cannot support the cited family-law proposition. The citation to Custody of Sorrel for that proposition appears to be erroneous or from a different case with the same caption, not this opinion.
Custody of Sorrel, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 903.relevant_excerpt: [No relevant passage: the opinion solely discusses duplicative criminal convictions (armed robbery, carjacking, larceny of a motor vehicle) and evidentiary issues, and does not address child custody, schooling, or welfare.]

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: A parent’s failure to foster a child’s education has been deemed a sufficient change in circumstance to warrant modification of custody or parenting time. See Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss any change in circumstances after an initial custody order, nor does it involve a modification proceeding. The court affirms an original award of sole custody to the mother and reduced visitation to the father based on broad best‑interests factors and parental conflict, including disagreements about schooling, but it does not hold that a parent’s failure to foster education is a sufficient changed circumstance warranting modification. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother… Although the husband had had involvement with the child rearing functions and responsibilities, the judge concluded that because the parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing, such as health care, religion and education, as well as in day-to-day decision making and philosophy of discipline, an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: A parent’s failure to foster a child’s education has been deemed a sufficient change in circumstance to warrant modification of custody or parenting time. See Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion in Adoption of Hugo is an adoption/care and protection case that compares two alternative adoptive placements based on the child’s best interests, focusing heavily on which caregiver can better address the child’s special developmental and educational needs. It does not involve a pre‑existing custody or parenting time order between parents, nor does it analyze whether a parent’s failure to foster a child’s education constitutes a ‘change in circumstance’ justifying modification. The case therefore does not provide authority for the specific modification-of-custody proposition for which it is cited.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: The judge concluded that, while Ms. L. is a caring and loving professional foster parent, she has no record of accomplishment similar to Ms. J.’s, which he determined is “critical” to Hugo’s future. He ruled that the trauma of Hugo’s removal from Ms. L. was outweighed by the long-term benefits of moving him to a family better able to help him address his developmental challenges... As to his finding that Ms. L. derived her income from foster care, the judge appropriately took note of disruptions within the foster family...

Stevens v. Stevens, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 60.raw_text: Stevens v. Stevens, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 606 (1988)
Stevens v. Stevens, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 60.proposition: Courts have further held that when one parent interferes with a child’s schooling, the Court may adjust custody or legal decision-making authority to protect the child’s educational welfare. See Stevens v. Stevens, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 606 (1988); Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
Stevens v. Stevens, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 60.support_reasoning: This is a Massachusetts criminal appeal about the definition of ‘operation’ of a motor vehicle in an OUI prosecution. It does not involve family law, custody, parental decision‑making, or a child’s schooling, nor does it discuss adjusting custody to protect a child’s educational welfare. The proposition attributed to Stevens v. Stevens is therefore unrelated to the actual subject and holding of this opinion, so the citation does not support the claimed proposition.
Stevens v. Stevens, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 60.relevant_excerpt:
“A person operates a motor vehicle within the meaning of G. L. c. 90, § 24, when, in the vehicle, he intentionally does any act or makes use of any mechanical or electrical agency which alone or in sequence will set in motion the motive power of that vehicle.” (p. 608)

“No objection was taken to the instruction, but we conclude that the failure to instruct further and to explain the meaning of the phrase here at issue created a substantial risk of a miscarriage of justice… It is for these reasons that we conclude that, in the circumstances, reversal of the conviction is required.” (pp. 610–611)

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Courts have further held that when one parent interferes with a child’s schooling, the Court may adjust custody or legal decision-making authority to protect the child’s educational welfare. See Stevens v. Stevens, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 606 (1988); Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not address interference with a child’s schooling, nor does it discuss adjusting custody or legal decision-making specifically to protect educational welfare. Instead, it reiterates the general best-interests standard and reverses a custody award because the judge focused improperly on the father’s alleged misconduct rather than the child’s overall welfare. There is no mention of school-related interference or a holding tied to educational decisions, so the case does not support the specific proposition cited.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied). … This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The award of custody to one parent is not a device to be used by judges to discipline the other parent for his or her ‘shortcomings.’”
